ca trÃ¹	- {Ca TrÃ¹ - an original art performance of academic character - has been preserved for the past 10 centuries.To appreciate Ca TrÃ¹ is to appreciate poetry and music. Ca TrÃ¹ appeared officially under NhÃ  Háº­u LÃ½ (11th century). First}\n- {it served royal and religious rituals and was called HÃ¡t KhuÃ´n. Later}\n- {it was used in banquets}\n- {weddings}\n- {friendly meetings... and called HÃ¡t HÃ ng Hoáº¡ Ca TrÃ¹ had bamboo castanets as principal+instrument. By beating time on tomtoms}\n- {spectators accompanied and praised the singer. Ca TrÃ¹ was also called HÃ¡t NhÃ  TrÃ² (singing or dancing while pulling funny tricks)}\n- {HÃ¡t ThÆ°á»Ÿng (Singing to be rewarded by king or mandarins)}\n- {HÃ¡t Cá»­a Quyá»n (singing in royal palaces)}\n- {HÃ¡t Cá»­a ÄÃ¬nh (singing for religious rituals)}\n- {HÃ¡t áº£ Ä‘Ã o (name of a famous songstress in the LÃ½ times).... Under the French domination}\n- {Ca TrÃ¹ declined. Nowadays}\n- {it is restored as a type of original popular art}\n- {What is a Ca TrÃ¹ declamation? Originally}\n- {Ca TrÃ¹ was like chÃ¨o singing and served at ceremonies and festivals in the northern delta. When these ceremonies and festivals were no longer held}\n- {Ca TrÃ¹ became a type of chamber music serving as intellectual food for those who would like to enjoy music and poetry}\n- {Music and poetry are the basis of Ca TrÃ¹ and decide which ensemble of principal instruments}\n- {musicians and subordinate instruments should provide the accompaniment. Ca TrÃ¹ has many melodies that are sung differently}\n- {but the chief is singing-reciting: A singer and a musician playing a long-necked lute-like instrument. Also taking part is a member of the audience who expresses his appreciation and response by beating a drum. A rather special description fits the songstress of former days: "Fine clothes}\n- {velvet turban}\n- {delicate bobtailed hair}\n- {a moon-shaped face}\n- {knife-sharp eyes}\n- {refined manners}\n- {with sweet words}\n- {mild as flowers}\n- {transparent as snow}\n- {the+singer must practise very hard and know many tunes. A male musician accompanies the singer. He too practises hard so as to be in perfect harmony with the singer. The music accompaniment consists of a "phÃ¡ch" - a bamboo instrument beaten with two wooden sticks - and "trá»‘ng cháº§u" - a drum beaten by a member of the audience in appreciation or comment. Of course}\n- {this member of the audience is very experienced at beating the drum - a single beat}\n- {three or five successive beats and nine beats at the climax to be "in tune" with the lute. A timely response by the drummer encourages the singer who knows that she has met someone who both understands and appreciates her talent. These three instruments: The lute}\n- {the "phÃ¡ch" and the "trá»‘ng cháº§u" are inseparable. Being a subordinate+instrument}\n- {the drum is essential as a bridge between the performer and audience. The harmonious combination of the lute}\n- {the "phÃ¡ch" and the+human voice makes it a perfect performance as praised in these lines by VÅ© HoÃ ng ChÆ°Æ¡ng: Sweet phach}\n- {passionate lute mild smoke cushion. The sad voice lingers on in the middle of night. To enjoy Ca TrÃ¹ is to enjoy both music and singing. The art of Ca TrÃ¹ is both high and original. Its sound range originates from that of the lullaby in the Red River delta. Ca TrÃ¹ - with water puppetry - is+indigenous to Vietnam. It is a valuable legacy for Vietnamese culture}\n- {Many talented poets like Chu Máº¡nh Trinh}\n- {Nguyá»…n CÃ´ng Trá»©}\n- {TÃº XÆ°Æ¡ng}\n- {DÆ°Æ¡ng KhuÃª and Táº£n ÄÃ  composed excellent tunes}\n- {extraordinarily pure and high-falutin to charm the audience.+At the beginning of the 20th century}\n- {before the 1945}\n- {there were many places where Ca TrÃ¹ was performed: KhÃ¢m ThiÃªn}\n- {Bá»“ Äá»}\n- {Lá»™ KhÃª (Hanoi)}\n- {Quan Ba Mau}\n- {Quá»³nh CÆ° (Háº£i PhÃ²ng) and throughout Báº¯c Ninh}\n- {Háº£i DÆ°Æ¡ng and Nam Äá»‹nh provinces. But then}\n- {Ca TrÃ¹ became CÃ´ Äáº§u - performed by a sing-song girl or type of geisha. The art of Ca TrÃ¹ was forgotten because it was thought to be a product of the ruling+class}\n- {the singers whores and the audience no more than hedonists. Singers abandoned their careers because of this bias and inhabitants of the KhÃ¢m ThiÃªn area even left their homes because of it. Before 1976}\n- {musician Nguyá»…n XuÃ¢n KhoÃ¡t was the only Vietnamese musicologist to study Ca TrÃ¹. Ca TrÃ¹ artists are still rare now}\n- {but attention is being given their art. Lá»™ KhÃª village}\n- {Phu Do (in HÃ  Ná»™i) is considered the cradle of Ca TrÃ¹ and on the 6th of the 4th lunar month and the 13th of the tenth lunar month each year}\n- {members of the Ca TrÃ¹ circle hold initiator-worshipping celebrations Artists young and old sing the Ca TrÃ¹}\n- {always beginning with two pieces: Non Mai and Há»“ng Háº¡nh.+The artist who deserves most praise for the revival and world-wide spread of Ca TrÃ¹ is Doctor-Professor Tráº§n VÄƒn Khá»‡ He has recorded Ca TrÃ¹}\n- {Quan Há» and chÃ¨o songs and declamations and sent them to France for the UNESCO Musical Committee to study. As a result}\n- {many recordings of Ca TrÃ¹ and Quan Há» songs have been made. The support of eminent artist QuÃ¡ch Thá»‹ Há»“ has made the recordings a great success. All the original features of Ca TrÃ¹ are prominent}\n- {and Há»“ was evaluated by the Musical+Committee and awarded with an honorary commendation with these lines: "We thank you for your contribution to the keeping of an original}\n- {traditional art legacy of Vietnam and an exceptional delicacy of mankind". Since then}\n- {English}\n- {German and Japanese. American researcher Mirada Krenzen has written a persuasive study}\n- {a fermented substance to charm the listeners. Once I understood Ca TrÃ¹}\n- {I understood the Vietnamese people better". It is possible that Ca TrÃ¹ is a patch of the Vietnamese soul that Krenzen has understood? ()}

chiÃªng	- {Gong} ã‚´ãƒ³ã‚°, éŠ…é‘¼\n- {Gongs were found in Vietnam in the Bronze Age (ÄÃ´ng SÆ¡n culture from 2000 to 3500 years ago). Gongs were cast in bronze}\n- {an alloy of copper}\n- {zinc and lead. Gongs are used as a musical instrument by most ethnic groups in Vietnam. Gongs are frequently mentioned in Highland songs}\n- {and its music displays its contemplative nature. Highlanders believe that when gong music is played}\n- {there is an encounter between the human and spirit worlds}\n- {between the worlds of the living and the dead. In real life}\n- {the gong is closely associated with each stage of a lifespan. In the ceremony of blowing the ear for a newborn child}\n- {the sound of a gong serves to declare the offical acceptance of a new community member. When he or she is old enough to get married}\n- {in the ceremony of exchanging necklace}\n- {the gong seems to urge young people to dash to the battlefield and struggle for the survival of the community. If the gong sounds hilarious and fast}\n- {it heralds a victory or the ceremony of killing buffalo. When the gong sounds slow}\n- {sinister and heavy}\n- {then it is the news of a death. The gong is warm in a night of rest or around a fire with a pot of wine}\n- {an indication of a good harvest when young people gather to sing and dance and tell of their love}\n- {When the gong sounds from the communal house}\n- {it can be heard all over the mountain and forest as a call for the young men to return to the communal house. When an old man passes away}\n- {the gong echoes its farewell. Virtually}\n- {all Western Highland and Long Range tribes have their own gongs. There are various types: Cá»“ng (with a nipple) and ChiÃªng (without one) and there are also different sizes depending on the tribe}\n- {each region with its own regulations. It would not be an exaggeration to say that the gong is one of the main instruments in the orchestras of the Western Highland (TÃ¢y NguyÃªn) and Long Range (TrÆ°á»ng SÆ¡n) tribes}\n- {used in festivals such as the welcoming of a victory}\n- {killing buffalo}\n- {forgetting a tomb}\n- {and welcoming a good harvest. There are three pieces: Juar}\n- {Trum and Vang. Juar has an accelerating tempo revealing the majestic heroism of the victory}\n- {Trum (accompanied by a shield dance) expresses the hard but brave fight of the soldiers}\n- {and Vang}\n- {with a slow tempo}\n- {tells of sorrow}\n- {grief and regret felt for fallen soldiers. Gongs are named differently according to their size}\n- {register} ãƒ¬ã‚¸ã‚¹ã‚¿, ãƒ¬ã‚¸ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼, éŸ³åŸŸ, è¨˜å, æ›¸ãè¨˜ã™, å°å¸³, å¸³ç°¿, ç™»éŒ²\n- {timbre and function: Mother Gong}\n- {Father Gong}\n- {Older Sister Gong}\n- {Younger Sister Gong}\n- {or high pitch}\n- {medium pitch and low pitch. Hands or sticks are used to beat the gong. Sticks can be wrapped with cloth and/or rubber and a gong can be held by hand}\n- {put on the thigh or hung on a frame when played. Researchers all agree that of all the gongs of the ethnic groups}\n- {the Ba Na gong is the most majestic}\n- {imposing} å®å£®, ç«‹æ´¾, å‡›ã€…ã—ã„, å‡›å‡›ã—ã„\n- {romantic and echoing}\n- {the Gia Rai gong is the most solid}\n- {echoing and accelerated. chÃ´m chÃ´m	- {Rambutan}\n- {A rambutan tree has a broad foliage and many branches. The tree yields fruit at the beginning of the rainy season in the southern provinces. The}\n- {Chom fruit season finishes at the end of the rainy season (from May to}\n- {October). The skin of the fruit is tough}\n- {thick and hairy. cá»‘i xay	- {Mill} å·¥å ´
cá»‘m	- {Green rice flakes}\n- {Rice growing farmers are the only ones who truly understand when it is time to gather young grains to make Cá»‘m. Then young rice grains are harvested}\n- {roasted and ground down to become Cá»‘m. They are put into a large firing pan under small flames and stirred slowly for a specific period of time. They are then poured into a rice mortar and slightly pounded with a wooden pestle}\n- {rythmically and at quick intervals until the husk is removed. Following this}\n- {the young rice is removed from the mortar and winnowed before being poured again into the mortar and the process repeated. This is then repeated exactly seven times so that all the husk is removed from the young sticky grains. If the pounding is done irregularly and in haste}\n- {or it is not repeated for the prescribed seven times}\n- {the green colour of the grains will disappear and be replaced by an unexpected brown colour. Cá»‘m is regarded as a purely pastoral gift. To enjoy Cá»‘m}\n- {it is advisable to chew it slowly so that one can feel the stickiness of the young rice and at the same time enjoy its sweet}\n- {fragrant taste. Visitors to Vong village (about five km from Hanoi) during the Cá»‘m making season will have a chance to listen to the special rythmic pounding of wooden pestles against mortars filled with young rice and see women shifting and winnowing the pounded young rice}

Legend has it that King LÃ½ ThÃ¡i TÃ´n was very old and had no son of his own. Therefore}\n- {he had a dream that he was granted a private audience with Buddha with a male baby in his hands. lÃ ng	- {Village} ãƒ“ãƒ¬ãƒƒã‚¸, é›†è½, æ‘, é‡Œ\n- {Set} ä¸€æƒã„, ä¸€æƒãˆ\n- {table (in a game)}\n- {circles}\n- {FLOATING VILLAGES: Rearing fish in cages under rafts has become increasingly common in a number of countries}\n- {but perhaps nowhere is this occupation as advantageous as in Vietnam with its maze of rivers and streams criss-crossing the country from north to south}\n- {from west to east}\n- {totalling perhaps millions of kilometres in length.When it comes to raising fish in cages}\n- {has the biggest number of cages and produces more caged fish than any other locality in the country. It is no exaggeration to say that the fishing rafts on AnGiang rivers are true floating villages.If you ever come to AnGiang}\n- {do not fail to visit Cá»“n TiÃªn where you can fully appreciate the poetic nature of such villages. They are made of large rafts of either bamboo or timber depending on the capabilities of the fish raisers. In most cases}\n- {they are timber rafts measuring about 12 by 5 metres and 3 metres in height. After five months -- the usual time for the fish to complete their life cycle -- the family of the fish raiser anchors the raft on some part of the Tiá»n}\n- {Háº­u}\n- {or ChÃ¢u Äá»‘c rivers or any major canals. At present}\n- {most districts in AnGiang such as Long XuyÃªn}\n- {ChÃ¢u Äá»‘c}\n- {Chá»£ Má»›i}\n- {PhÃº TÃ¢n}\n- {PhÃº ChÃ¢u and ChÃ¢u PhÃº raise caged fish}\n- {but this occupation is still essentially practised in Cá»“n TiÃªn village}\n- {ChÃ¢u Äá»‘c township Cá»“n TiÃªn has the advantage of being located near the supply centre for young fish and fish meal (the ChÃ¢u Äá»‘c market) and also on a fast-flowing river. Cá»“n TiÃªn actually accounts for almost half of all the fish rafts of AnGiang provincáº¹The two main fish species raised in cages in AnGiang are the Ba Sa and Chai which take their food from the water surface. Their food consists chiefly of rice bran mixed with vegetables such as pumpkin.A raft for rearing 50}\n- {000 Ba Sa fish needs about 3}\n- {500 kilograms of food}\n- {but for rearing 10}\n- {000 to 20}\n- {000 Chai}\n- {only 00 to 800 kilos of food are required. One raft needs only three workhands. The first harvest from a raft averages 12 tonnes of Ba Sa and three tonnes of he or Chai fish.+Net profit may account for 25 % - 30 % of the proceeds. But not everything has been plain sailing for the fish raisers of AnGiang. At its peak year}\n- {AnGiang had 1}\n- {200 rafts. In 1971}\n- {there were only 662 and the number slumped to 225 in 1980. A rapid recovery began in 1984}\n- {when the local government decreed new policies on prices and on the rearing and marketing of caged fish. Early in 1990}\n- {the AnGiang Aquatic Produce Import- Export Company loaned fish raisers three billion dong. It also found markets for caged fish in Australia}\n- {Hong Kong and Singapore. Subsequently}\n- {the number of rafts rose to 715 and fish output to 14}\n- {000 tonnes}\n- {double the figures for 1989. The expansion also provided jobs for 4}\n- {000 people. One of the biggest problems in caged fish raising in AnGiang is the supply of young fish}\n- {since most of them come from natural breeding. Production of all other fish still depends on natural breeding. Research and experimentation in this direction with regard to fish such as Ba Sa}\n- {Chai and Bong are going on at the provincial sciences committee. In recent years}\n- {caged fish raising has also been undertaken by other provinces such as HÃ  TÃ¢y}\n- {HÃ  Báº¯c and VÄ©nh PhÃº in the north and Háº­u Giang}\n- {Äá»“ng ThÃ¡p and Long An in the south. In HÃ  TÃ¢y province west of HÃ  Ná»™i}\n- {200 families in the district of Ba VÃ¬}\n- {Dan PhÆ°Æ¡ng and Má»¹ Äá»©c keep more than 200 fish cages along the ÄÃ  and Red Rivers. Ba VÃ¬ district alone has 165 cages}\n- {mainly raising Indian carp. They yield from two to three tonnes of fish per cage. On average}\n- {the fish raisers get from 16 to 24 million dong in income and about seven million in net profit. Riverside villages such as Thuan My}\n- {Tay Dang}\n- {Co Do and Minh ChÃ¢u are gradually shifting from fishing in the river to raising fish in cages. The administration in Ba VÃ¬ has made a uniform loan of one million dong to every family of fish raisers. Experts are providing technical assistance to make fish spawn in the rivers}\n- {thus reducing production costs. Many families of farmers are also raising fish as a secondary occupation besides cultivation. One thousand families of farmers in Ba VÃ¬ district have registered for caged fish raising}

National Construction and Defence for National Independence lasted about one thousand years (from the early 10th Century to the middle of the 19th Century). This period also witnessed several fierce struggles launched by the Vietnamese people against the northern aggressors. The wars of resistance included the battle against the Tá»‘ng army in the 11th century}\n- {three separate wars against the invading Mongol army in the 13rd century}\n- {and the resistance against the Minh army in the 14th century. In the late 17th century}\n- {the Vietnamese feudal nation was faced with a social and economic crisis that led to an annexation of the country into two parts. However}\n- {the victory of the TÃ¢y SÆ¡n revolt at the close of the 18th century reunified the country. In the first half of the 19th century}\n- {the Nguyá»…n dynasty continued to consolidate national unification. Yet}\n- {a prevailing conservative attitude among Nguyá»…n dynasty court officials allowed the country to drift into a period of stagnation and Vietnam eventually became a French colony. At present}\n- {the Vietnamese people are trying to develop their national economy in a very difficult situation mostly due to the dictatorship of the Vietnamese communist goverment. Now}\n- {In the ancient times}\n- {Red River Civilization succeeded the native prehistoric cultures. To have an overview of the Vietnamese culture}\n- {see also CÃ¡c Ná»n VÄƒn HoÃ¡ á»– Viá»‡t Nam}\n- {Restoration of cultural and historical monuments in Vietnam: Vietnam has 979 classified national monuments relics including 497 historical monuments}\n- {440 ancient architectures (pagodas}\n- {temples and communal houses)}\n- {30 scenic places and 12 archaeological sites. Others were heavily damaged such as many temples}\n- {pagodas}\n- {churches and other places of worship in northern Vietnam Nature has also taken its toll. Conservation work has been compounded by growing appropriation of public lands by people for house construction}\n- {especially in the towns The government has taken positive steps in recent years to restore some of the most significant historical relies like the old capital in Huáº¿}\n- {central Vietnam}\n- {Cá»• Loa Citadel}\n- {the first capital of Vietnam}\n- {the ancient capital of Hoa LÆ° in Nam HÃ  province}\n- {or the temples of the HÃ¹ng Kings}\n- {founders of the Vietnamese nation nearly 4}\n- {000 years ago. Vietnamese restorers have found a solution by drawing upon the experience of builders in the past. A common method is either to fill hollowed-out pillars with concrete or to replace them with new ones. But both have their drawbacks. In the first case}\n- {the concrete would detach from the wood within a few years. In the latter case}\n- {the cost involved and the risk of collapse during the replacement would be high.To solve the problem}\n- {Vietnamese restorers have combined the use of traditional termite killers with the spraying of chemicals into the infested pillars. That would both kill the insects and prevent the growth of fungi. They can gnaw away each year from 0.2mm to.5mm of wood. But what is more damaging is that the humid secretion they leave on the surface will create the necessary environment for the development of fungi. This damage can be best seen at Keo Pagoda in ThÃ¡i BÃ¬nh province}\n- {100 km southeast of HÃ  Ná»™i}\n- {where several hundred iron-wood pillars have been virtually eaten up.}

Gradually}\n- {it came to be used as a musical instrument producing familiar sounds and rhythms. It might have come into existence long before the Viá»‡t community knew how to melt copper to make bronze drums and bronze bells for musical instruments.}

nháº¡c cá»¥	- {Musical instrument} æ¥½å™¨\n- {VIETNAMESE TRADITIONAL MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS: Vietnamese traditional instruments have a rich capacity for expression and are unique. This is shown in many ways. In general}\n- {Vietnamese traditional instruments are of simple structure. Sometimes too simple to be called instruments. For example}\n- {the leaf-horn has only two requirements: The surface of the leaf should be smooth and the leaf itself not thick. A girl holds the "horn" by the edge in her mouth and begins to produce a shrill sound. After a "performance}\n- {another flute}\n- {has only two holes - one for blowing and the other for fingering - but it can produce music written from the five-note scale. Castanets are simply two bamboo pieces}\n- {a bamboo end can become a split drum}\n- {kouniak and gourd covering is available in the garden. Further afield can be found bamboo}\n- {kouniak}\n- {wood} ã‚¦ãƒƒãƒ‰, æœ¨, æœ¨æ\n- {clay} ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒ¼, é™¶ç£, ç²˜åœŸ\n- {leather} ãƒ¬ã‚¶ãƒ¼, é©, çš®, çš®é©\n- {stonáº¹.. Only the parts of instruments are difficult to make. For example}\n- {with an organ the trick is to stick a reed into one end for blowing. But simple or not}\n- {these instruments are so skilfully made as to be works of art. Their sizes are also unique. Clappers can be as small as a longan kernel}\n- {a certain drum is no bigger than a lemon. Other instruments are huge. The lithophone}\n- {or Ndut Lieng Krak}\n- {is 01.7cm long and the KhÃ¡nh SÆ¡n 103cm while lithophones found in other parts of the world are only 80cm long. The Qui Dien bell}\n- {cast in 1080 in the times of NhÃ  Háº­u LÃ½ and NhÃ  Tráº§n}\n- {needed a 26 meter-high bell tower to house it. Another bell of the same period was cast in about 4}\n- {200 tonnes of bronze. The Van Ban bell with 180 tons in weight}\n- {made under NhÃ  Tráº§n}\n- {is 127cm high and has a diameter 74 cm. The bronze drum}\n- {especially the Son Dong drum}\n- {is huge}\n- {imposing and beautiful. The Thunder drum}\n- {which sounds like thunder}\n- {has a 148 cm diameter and is 170 cm high Some drums have a circumference of two metres and are made from the trunk of a banyan tree. Gongs and cymbals range from saucer-size to a plate 90cm in diameter. The different sizes mean that Vietnamese traditional instruments all carry characteristics stemming from the artistic creativity of the people.- Nevertheless}\n- {their capacity is both abundant and unique. On the Ä‘Ã n nguyá»‡t}\n- {the musician is able to "stress" a note making it a triple-interval higher note or vice versa. The Ä‘Ã n dÃ¢y}\n- {a type of lute}\n- {also has available a "loose stress" and on the Ä‘Ã n báº§u}\n- {monocord}\n- {a half-note}\n- {a third of a note}\n- {a quarter of a note and perhaps even less than a quarter of a note can be created. An even more subtle characteristic of the monocord is that the fingered string}\n- {touched}\n- {can produce a note lower than that made by the unfingered string. This cannot be done on any other instruments. The one-stringed monocord has a three-octave range}\n- {although some improved monocords have a four-octave range. The klongput makes sound without being touched by the musician Another technique worthy of study is that which allows musicians to play such horns as pile and xaranai to make a continuous sound without pausing or stopping. Vietnamese traditional instruments are close to the lives of the people and their activities. Vietnamese instruments - particularly primitive instruments - are part of their activities.}

nÃ´ng nghiá»‡p	- {Agriculture} ã‚¢ã‚°ãƒªã‚«ãƒ«ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼, è¾², è¾²å­¦, è¾²æ¥­, è¾²è€•\n- {farming} è€•ä½œ, è¾², è¾²è€•\n- {CEREMONIES STILL AT THE HEART OF AGRICULTURE IN VIETNAM: Lá»… Háº¡ Äiá»n is a popular ceremony which bears a religious significance for Vietnamese farmers. During the ceremony}\n- {farmers pray to heaven to grant them blessings. As Vietnam is an agricultural country where labour-intensive wet-rice is grown}\n- {the life of the majority of people is closely linked with the land. Hence}\n- {almost all ceremonies and rituals are connected with farming. Wet-rice is grown in very difficult natural conditions}\n- {especially in the Red River Delta and central Vietnam where natural calamities - typhoons}\n- {flooding} å† æ°´\n- {drought and pests - are a constant menace for the peasantry. In the past}\n- {in the absence of science and technology}\n- {Vietnamese farmers believed in mysterious forces which decided their success or failure. This faith is found in such folk songs as "Thanks to heaven which grants us good weather conditions" or "I pray to heaven to bring rain so that I can have enough water to drink and cover my fields". Heaven (or Trá»i in Vietnamese) is a common appellation for the spirit world. The belief in the power of spirits is handed down from generation to generation}\n- {so that even now our farmers turn to spirits for assistance. Hence the existence of so many farming-related ceremonies. In the past}\n- {there were two main rice crops: the MÃ¹a and the ChiÃªm Depending on climate and local understanding}\n- {farmers regard the ChiÃªm as the main crop}\n- {or vice versa. For this reason}\n- {Lá»… Háº¡ Äiá»n differs from one region to another. In many villages}\n- {the ceremony is regarded as a major event in the life of the peasantry. Although the ceremonies may differ in scale}\n- {the rituals have many common features. On the day of the ceremony}\n- {early in the morning} æœæ—©ã\n- {village notables called GiÃ  LÃ ng (elder people) in the central highlands make their way to the communal house where other villagers await. There they pay tribute to ThÃ nh HoÃ ng (tutelary god) and Tháº§n NÃ´ng (god of agriculture) and other divinities}\n- {begging them to bring security}\n- {prosperity and bumper crops. Afterwards}\n- {the villagers head to a chosen location}\n- {usually not too far from the communal house}\n- {where the ceremony inaugurating the farming season takes place. In a first-class rice field already meticulously ploughed and harrowed}\n- {a bamboo tree is planted with all its branches and leaves. The tree is called CÃ¢y Ne^u. Ears of rice are attached to the top of the tree}\n- {and having reported to the god of agriculture}\n- {they start the ceremony proper. To start the ball rolling}\n- {a rice transplant ritual is performed. For this}\n- {many ChÃºa Äá»“ng (Field Lords) are selected. In some villages}\n- {only one ChÃºa Äá»“ng is singled out. They are mostly elderly people}\n- {versed in farming techniques and the soil. In addition}\n- {they must be kind-hearted people having extended families whose members live in perfect concord. Last but not least}\n- {they should not be mourning People hope that the good qualities of the ChÃºa Äá»“ng will blend into the rice plants and impart great vitality to them. Having paid their respects to the god of agriculture}\n- {the ChÃºa Äá»“ng step into the field and transplant rice around the bamboo tree. In the meantime}\n- {the villagers shout cheerfully and beat drums (mimicking natural disaster)}\n- {targeting the ChÃºa Äá»“ng. If these people can stand firm on their feet and manage to perform their task well}\n- {people believe that their wish will come true Lá»… Háº¡ Äiá»n is held in a very simple way}\n- {but it is very dear to the  farmers. They pin all their hopes on the good health}\n- {prosperity and happiness that the ceremony promises. Furthermore}\n- {it is in this ceremony that the spirit of the community comes to the surface. In their hearts}\n- {everyone pledges to join forces for the common cause}

rÆ°á»£u cáº§n	- {RÆ°á»£u cáº§n (wine drunk out of a jar through pipes) is very popular among the highlanders}\n- {especially in TÃ¢y NguyÃªn. But its flavour differs from one area to another. In SÆ¡n La (some 300 km north-west of HÃ  Ná»™i)}\n- {for example} ä»®ã«, ä¾‹ãˆã°\n- {where the ThÃ¡i ethnic groups are to be found}\n- {people drink rÆ°á»£u cáº§n in their own special way. It is drunk on several occasions: Táº¿t festival}\n- {wedding parties}\n- {ground-breaking ceremonies or other festive days. The jar containing the wine is put at a fixed place (in the middle of the house or the yard)}\n- {so that as many people as possible can drink it. Pipes are put into the jar prior to drinking and a basinful of pure water is placed beside it. A buffalo horn to be used to pour water into the jar is put on a tray nearby. Not everyone is allowed to drink rÆ°á»£u cáº§n. And the order of precedence is strictly observed. But there is no racial discrimination: the Kinh ( Viá»‡t) may drink with the ThÃ¡i and MÆ°á»ng. The ingredients of rÆ°á»£u cáº§n include wild leaves}\n- {cassava roots and rice which are washed and put above an oven for 20 days or sá» Then all the mixed ingredients are wrapped with large banana leaves and left in a corner of the house for a couple of days. As soon as the process of fermentation is completed}\n- {the whole brew is put into a jar. When all the guests are seated}\n- {the host pours water from the basin into the jar. At first}\n- {he invites the guests to taste the wine from a jar whose wine is more bitter than others. This is meant to remind everyone of the bitterness of life. Then a second jar is brought in which the wine tastes more pungent. In the third jar}\n- {the wine is sweetest symbolizing that " your heart can be happy after so much grief". Drinking rÆ°á»£u cáº§n is accompanied by MÃºa XoÃ¨ (a dance of the ThÃ¡i ethnic minorities) and drum beating. All this is to help the host and guests forget all their daily worries and enjoy to the utmost the pleasure of tasting rÆ°á»£u cáº§n. (VNS)}

This mountain was the centre of the insurrection led by her. BÃ  Triá»‡u whose full name was Triá»‡u Thá»‹ Trinh was a beloved national heroine. She led the nation in an uprising against the northern invasion in the 3rd century. Ritual ceremonies are held yearly at the temple on the 21st day of the lunar second month. People on pilgrimage to the temple often recall BÃ  Triá»‡u s outright declaration: "I want to drive over strong wind}\n- {sail over strong waves and chase the foreign invaders out of the country}\n- {and I will not give up myself to be their servant-concubine". When peace returned in 1954}\n- {Vietnamese engineers applied new engineering techniques and built an iron bridge. The new HÃ m Rá»“ng bridge was completed on May 19}\n- {1964. The bridge gained fame because it became the main target of US air forces in the efforts to break the North-South supply lines}

ThÃ¡i	- {With nearly 900}\n- {000 inhabitants (1.45% of the Vietnamese population)}\n- {ThÃ¡i ethnic group is divided into ThÃ¡i tráº¯ng (White ThÃ¡i) and ThÃ¡i Ä‘en (Black ThÃ¡i) on the basis of the clothing colour. The residential sphere spreads from Red River right bank to Thanh HoÃ¡}\n- {Nghá»‡ An Highlands. It is easy for them to mix with native ethnic groups. They settle in valleys surrounding immense fields (MÆ°á»ng Thanh}\n- {Quang Huy}\n- {Than UyÃªn}\n- {NghÄ©a Lá»™)}\n- {and live on farming}\n- {breeding} è‚²ã¡, ç”Ÿè‚², èº¾\n- {weaving. The ThÃ¡i people has its own writing and a very developed popular culture}\n- {In the western part of Nghá»‡ An Province}\n- {there reside about 13}\n- {000 ethnic Thais belonging to the sub-groups of Tay Thanh}\n- {Tay Muoi}\n- {and others. Like their counterparts in the North-West of the country}\n- {the ThÃ¡i community here possesses a rich culture that has been built up over the centuries. In their everyday working life}\n- {the ThÃ¡i minority has developed a rich and abundant culture. Many traditional rites and festivals exist along with other ThÃ¡i cultural activities. In this article}\n- {the Cave-Visiting Festival of the ThÃ¡i people living in the mountain villages surrounding Quá»³ Há»£p dates back to time immemorial}\n- {the ThÃ¡i folk in and around the locality flock to the Cave - Picnicking Festival The event takes place in Tham Mon (Mon Cave) located in the ChÃ¢u Quy commune}\n- {Quá»³ Há»£p district. The Cave visitors are of all ages}\n- {but mainly single young people. They are natives from the villages of Quá»³ Há»£p and other neighbouring districts in West Nghá»‡ An. Visitors are allowed to enter the cave only once a day until they find themselves a boy or girl friend}\n- {and return home when the festival ends. It is an inviolable rule that cave visitors must not bring in a lamp}\n- {fire or any source of light.+All visitors come into the cave for the festive occasion amid complete darkness. Young people first enter in groups}\n- {then disperse and move further into the dark cave. Once inside the cave}\n- {the girls usually gather in small groups of two or three}\n- {and stand timidly in the cave alleys. The boys}\n- {also in small groups}\n- {grope in the dark for girl friends. Every action must be made by hand}\n- {and every move made by foot as calling}\n- {speaking or shouting are completely forbiÄ‘en... Having found a friend of the opposite sex}\n- {the boy can talk with and court the girl in the cave. If they find each other suitable}\n- {by assisting and creating favourable conditions for the couple to become husband and wife. That the Festival takes place in such a dark cave makes it an extremely fun-filled and enjoyable experience. All unmarried ThÃ¡i boys and girls are eager to go to the Cave- Visiting Festival to try their luck at seeking a life companion. The ThÃ¡i men traditionally look for a pretty girl of marriageable age who must be well-built and in good health Therefore}\n- {in the cave}\n- {a boy first makes sure that he finds himself the right girl}\n- {that is} ã“ã“ã§, å³ã¡\n- {he asks in whispers after her name}\n- {her whereabouts and her parents so as not to mistake a blood sister or relative whom he cannot marry. He then feels her thoroughly to find out whether she is strong and sturdy. If satisfied}\n- {he then starts to exchange intimacies}\n- {courts her and ultimately leads her out of the cave. Such a play of courtship all in the dark cave with the boys fumbling for the girls who hide themselves in the cave gorges or alleys cannot be free of conflicts and jostlings among the men. A struggle inevitably ensues when a boy finds a girl who has a flaw and tries to get rid of her. Similar to practices such as the "moonlight dance" or "moonlight stroll" of some other ethnic minorities}\n- {when social events were virtually non-existent among the ThÃ¡is}\n- {the Cave-Picnicking festival presented a good opportunity for young people to discover and exchange love. The Festival in fact was an indispensable part of the cultural life of the ThÃ¡i people in western Nghá»‡ An up to the first half of this century}

trá»‘ng cÆ¡m	- {Cylindrical drum}\n- {LEGEND OF "TRá»NG CÆ M". A famous song from Vietnamese folklore goes thus: "How joyful to have a Trá»‘ng CÆ¡m}\n- {and it is an honour for those who can clap it skilfully..."The lyrics and the melody are usually accompanied by a picture showing boy or girl drummers with axehead-shaped turbans over their heads and long-shaped drums hung loose from the neck down to about the belly... All these easily mislead the audience to believe that Trá»‘ng CÆ¡m (the Vietnamese cylindrical drum) is an ordinary musical instrument. In fact}\n- {in the national musical instrument ensemble}\n- {Trá»‘ng CÆ¡m contributes an unique sound - now happy and cheerful}\n- {now low}\n- {people stuck a handful of glutinous rice to each drumhead. Trá»‘ng CÆ¡m is used in worshipping and various ceremonies}\n- {in chÃ¨o (traditional operetta) and in PhÆ°á»ng BÃ¡t Ã‚m or an octet (a popular ensemble of eight instrumental timbres). The glutinous rice stuck against the drumhead lends its name to the drum (Trá»‘ng CÆ¡m in Vietnamese literally means "Rice Drum"). Legend goes that once upon a time}\n- {there was a poor Confucian disciple who was very unlucky in competitions and examinations and had to go begging. Everyday}\n- {he went past the mansion of a wealthy family where there was always a girl waiting to give him rice. One day}\n- {so moved and also ashamed by her good deed}\n- {the young man came to thank the girl. She however said that she had done just what she had been ordered to do by her young mistress. Learning that}\n- {the man requested to see the mistress}\n- {who was a kind-hearted girl.
